title: Epigenetic Modifications Underlying Symbiont-Host Interactions
abstract: The development, existence, and functioning of numerous animals and plants depend on their symbiotic interactions with other organisms, mainly microorganisms. In return, the symbionts benefit from safe habitats and nutrient-rich environments provided by their hosts. In these interactions, genetic changes in either of the partners may provide fitness advantages and become subjects to natural selection. Recent findings suggest that epigenetic changes, heritable or within the organism's life time, in either of the partners play significant roles in the establishment of symbiotic relationships. In this review, a variety of epigenetic effects underlying the most common host-symbiont interactions will be examined to determine to what extent these effects are shared in various interactions and how the epigenetic pathways could possibly be manipulated to benefit the interacting symbionts. Contents 1. Introduction 254 2. Unicellular Symbiotic Associations 255 3. Plant-Symbiont Associations 256 4. Coral-Algae Interaction 257 5. Insects 258 5.1 Wolbachia-Host Interactions 258 5.2 Endosymbionts of Tsetse Flies 263 6. Vertebrate Gut Microbiota 7. MicroRNAs As Epigenetic Regulators of Symbiotic Associations 8. Conclusions 269 Acknowledgments 271 References 271

abstract.text: The development, existence, and functioning of numerous animals and plants depend on their symbiotic interactions with other organisms, mainly microorganisms. In return, the symbionts benefit from safe habitats and nutrient-rich environments provided by their hosts. In these interactions, genetic changes in either of the partners may provide fitness advantages and become subjects to natural selection. Recent findings suggest that epigenetic changes, heritable or within the organism's life time, in either of the partners play significant roles in the establishment of symbiotic relationships. body_text.text: Symbiosis is widespread across the tree of life, being found in unicellular eukaryotes, sponges, fungi, invertebrates, vertebrates, and plants. This interaction is so common that the phenomenon is considered a rule rather than the exception. Symbiotic microbial flora often provides nutrients that cannot be synthesized by the host or are rare in the host's diet and as a consequence allows the hosts to expand their habitats. In symbiotic associations, the interacting organisms produce factors that can regulate the gene expression profiles of the parties involved in the interaction, referred to as "interspecies epigenesis" (Gilbert, 2002) . As a consequence, there is reciprocal gene regulation that involves molecular cross talk between the interacting organisms.

In symbiotic relationships, the combination of a host and its whole symbiotic population can be envisaged as the "holobiont" sharing a "hologenome" (Rosenberg, Koren, Reshef, Efrony, & Zilber-Rosenberg, 2007) or "symbiogenome" (Provrov & Vorob'ev, 2012) . From an evolutionary perspective, natural selection may favor a hologenome due to fitness benefits conferred by the association shaping the evolutionary forces. Often epigenetic changes in one of the partners may benefit the holobiont to improve its tolerance to environmental stresses and unfavorable conditions (Gilbert et al., 2010) . This may be a source of natural variations and evolutionary novelties among symbiont populations occupying one host, which could be selected for or against based on environmental conditions leading to "symbiont shuffling"; one strain replacing the dominant strain in response to environmental changes (Goulet, 2006) . Therefore, genetic or microbial variations in the symbiont populations within a host that might affect the host's phenotype could be considered as epigenetic variations given the changes are inherited from one generation to the next without any changes in the host genome (Gilbert et al., 2010) .

Heritable epigenetic effects mostly include DNA methylation, modification of chromatin structure via alterations in histone interactions with DNA and proteins, and RNA interference. DNA methylation at adenine and cytosine nucleotides is a phylogenetically deeply conserved modification in prokaryotes and eukaryotes to regulate gene expression by affecting the affinity of transcription factors and other regulatory DNA-binding proteins. Modifications to histones, such as acetylation, lysine and arginine methylation, phosphorylation, and ubiquitination, can alter chromatin structure, change their affinity for DNA, or modify binding sites for protein recognition modules and thereby affect gene expression. Further, microR-NAs (miRNAs) as small noncoding RNAs have emerged as key molecules in regulating expression of genes involved in almost all cellular pathways in the majority of eukaryotes. Here, a number of symbiotic associations based on available information will be examined, mainly focusing on mutualistic interactions, to assess our current understanding of epigenetic effects underlying the host-symbiont interactions.

An interesting instance of mutualistic symbiosis in unicellular eukaryotes is the xD strain of Amoeba proteus, which appeared after infection of the D strain of the amoeba with the bacterium Legionella jeonii (Jeon & Lorch, 1967) . This association has become an obligatory symbiosis given the bacterium is essential for the survival of the xD strain (Jeon & Ahn, 1978) . The consequences of this symbiosis have been distinct physiological alterations in the xD strain, as compared to the D strain that does not harbor L. jeonii. One such alteration is the lack of transcription of one of the two S-adenosylmethionine synthase genes (sams1) in the xD strain (Choi, Lee, Jeon, & Ahn, 1997) . The enzyme converts methionine and adenosine triphosphate into S-adenosylmethionine (SAM). In the xD strain, expression of sams1 is switched to sams2 gene (Jeon & Jeon, 2004) , and this is believed to have contributed to the establishment of the symbiosis (Jeon & Jeon, 2004) .

A follow-up study to unravel the molecular mechanism of the lack of expression of the sams1 gene in the xD strain demonstrated methylation of adenine at an internal GATC site of the sams1 gene in the xD amoeba that harbors the symbiont. This residue was not methylated in the symbiont-free D strain (Jeon, 2008) . Moreover, when the bacteria were removed from xD amoeba, sams1 transcription was reactivated after 8 days postremoval. Cytosine methylation is more common in eukaryotes but adenine methylation is common in prokaryotes and also has been reported in some of the lower eukaryotes including ciliates (Hattman, 2005) . Notably, the study showed that some of the adenine residues in the sams gene in L. jeonii were also methylated. The source of DNA adenine methylase is currently unknown but it was speculated that it could be transported from L. jeonii to the cytoplasm of the amoeba or the bacteria may induce expression of such methylases in the host (Jeon, 2008) . This example clearly demonstrates that epigenetic modifications of the host upon interaction with an endosymbiont, that contribute to the establishment of symbiosis, may occur in evolutionarily basal taxa.

In plants, symbionts play significant roles in plant growth, development, and health by providing nutrients and increasing tolerance to biotic and abiotic stress factors. For example, endophytic fungi are very common in plants and many studies have shown that they increase growth and development of colonized plants (Rodriguez, White, Arnold, & Redman, 2009) . This is mainly achieved by promoting root growth through the allocation of resources to the expanding root system before stem growth (Rodriguez, Freeman, McArthur, Kim, & Redman, 2009) . Indeed, evidence suggests that some of these effects are due to epigenetic effects of plant symbiotic fungi or bacteria on their hosts. Conversely, during the course of the establishment of endosymbiosis, genetic and/or epigenetic changes occur in the interacting microorganisms with plant hosts.

In an interesting study, it was shown that the DNA adenine methylation of the plant root symbiontic bacterium Mesorhizobium loti considerably changes in the process of symbiosis with their host plants (Ichida, Matsuyama, Abe, & Koba, 2007) . The bacterium is important for nitrogen fixation in legume roots. The enzyme involved in the methylation is cellcycle-regulated methyltransferase, which is a solitary DNA methyltransferase in bacteria that catalyzes the transfer of a methyl group from SAM to the adenine nucleotide in GANTC motif (Wion & Casadesús, 2006) . While adenine in most of the GANTC sites is methylated in M. loti, there are sites within the genome that remain unmethylated known as specifically unmethylated regions (SUMs) (Ichida et al., 2007) . Intriguingly, SUMs become methylated during the process of symbiogenesis. These epigenetic modifications of the M. loti genome were found to be required for efficient nodulation, although the correct pattern of methylation was found not to be essential for establishment of the plant-microbe symbiosis (Ichida, Yoneyama, Koba, & Abe, 2009) .

In potato plants, responsiveness of two strains of potato to the beneficial bacterial endophyte Burkholderia phytofirmans strain PsJN is influenced by cytosine DNA methylation of the host genome, which in turn affects the expression levels of genes that may determine the outcome of the interaction (Da, Nowak, & Flinn, 2012) . In the poorly responsive strain (Superior), significantly higher methylation levels were detected compared to the strongly responsive strain (Red Pontiac). This suggested that hypermethylation of genomic DNA in the poorly responsive strain may be responsible for a decrease in B. phytofirmans-induced plant growth.

Symbionts have been demonstrated to contribute significantly to plant tolerance to stress and this could be regarded as an epigenetic plasticity trait. For example, the endophytic fungus Piriformospora indica confers drought tolerance in plants by colonizing their roots. In Arabidopsis, it was shown that in P. indica-colonized plants several genes were upregulated earlier and in higher quantities compared to uncolonized plants (Sherameti, Tripathi, Varma, & Oelmüller, 2008) . Among the upregulated genes was histone acetyltransferase, which is responsible for histone acetylation. Higher histone acetylation is associated with more active transcription. It is likely that by induction of this gene early, P. indica regulates expression of a variety of genes involved in stress response, which leads to priming the aerial parts of the plant to be more prepared for water stress.

Coral-algae mutualistic association has evolved over millions of years, in which the unicellular dinoflagellate, Symbiodinium, provides oxygen and organic compounds as products of photosynthesis to the coral and in return receives from the host inorganic nutrients and a safe habitat. Unfortunately, today coral reefs are under threat by increases in sea temperature, which lead to the death of the endosymbiotic Symbiodinium (Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007) . The loss of the endosymbiont results in bleaching of corals and their eventual demise (Glynn, 1984) . The genetic diversity present within the Symbiodinium genus might provide a source for selection of strains that are more thermotolerant responding better to environmental stress leading to strain switching (Jones, Berkelmans, van Oppen, Mieog, & Sinclair, 2008; Robinson & Warner, 2006) , as evidence suggests that little genetic differences in the symbionts populations can affect coral bleaching susceptibility (Sampayo, Ridgway, Bongaerts, & Hoegh-Guldberg, 2008) .

The role of plastic and inherited epigenetic effects in the regulation of gene expression in response to environmental stress is evident in diverse groups of living organisms. Evidence indicates that preconditioning of coralalgae holobiont with sublethal temperatures acclimatize it to be more tolerant to subsequent heat stresses (Maynard, Anthony, Marshall, & Masiri, 2008) . Transcriptomic studies revealed that at least nine genes were differentially expressed in preconditioned corals that maintained Symbiodinium density in comparison to nonpreconditioned Acropora millepora coral (Bellantuono, Granados-Cifuentes, Miller, Hoegh-Guldberg, & Rodriguez-Lanetty, 2012) . Furthermore, the results suggested that the preconditioning of the coral prevents an extreme transcriptional response, since several genes were codifferentially expressed in preconditioned and nonpreconditioned corals but the magnitude was mainly different. However, this study did not look into differential expression of Symbiodinium genes in response to heat stress. Considering the importance of the symbiont and its sensitivity to heat stress, which eventually affects the coral, it will be of relevance to examine the impact of heat on the symbiont's transcriptome.

Intriguingly, transcriptome analysis of Symbiodinium demonstrated that the transcriptional regulation of the symbiont might differ from mechanisms known in eukaryotes when compared with nonsymbiotic closely related species, for example, a lower number of transcription factors in the symbiont and mainly dominated by the cold shock domain and a high number of antioxidative genes (Bayer et al., 2012) . Consistent with scant number of reports on transcriptomics of corals and their symbionts, there is very little known about the role of epigenetics in coral-algae interactions. Given that evidence exists in a variety of nonmarine symbiotic interactions, host/symbiont reciprocal regulation of gene expression governed by epigenetic factors, which play central roles in establishment of symbiosis, are expected. Understanding factors that modulate the symbiotic relationships may contribute to efforts in saving the elimination of coral due to environmental stress and consequent loss of endosymbionts.

Endosymbionts have played a significant role in the evolutionary success of several groups of insects, including blood-feeding insects, cockroaches, sap-sucking insects, weevils, termites, ants, and perhaps many more to be discovered. Apart from nutritional values, endosymbionts provide additional fitness benefits such as protection against pathogens. Examples below show only representative instances in which epigenetic modifications in the host or the symbiotic microorganism are known.

Wolbachia pipientis is an α-proteobacterium endosymbiont that is widespread among nematodes and arthropods, estimated to be present in over 40% of insect species (Zug & Hammerstein, 2012) . Wolbachia is mostly known for reproductive manipulations of its host as a manifestation of its epigenetic effect on the host. These effects are transgenerational through the vertical transmission of the endosymbiont via the germ line. Wolbachia-induced maternal effects include male killing and feminization, parthenogenesis, and most notably cytoplasmic incompatibility (CI) (Stouthamer, Breeuwer, & Hurst, 1999) .

CI allows Wolbachia to rapidly spread in insect populations because infected females produce viable progeny if they mate with Wolbachiainfected or noninfected males, whereas when noninfected females mate with infected males no progeny is produced. This provides a reproductive advantage for the Wolbachia-infected female leading to rapid establishment of Wolbachia and its associated female genotype in a population (Hoffman & Turelli, 2007) . This property could be utilized for introducing pathogenresistance traits introduced through genetic modification, paratransgenesis (genetic modification of endosymbiont), or pathogen-inhibiting Wolbachia strains (Hoffmann et al., 2011; Sinkins & O'Neill, 2000) . Although the exact mechanisms behind CI and other maternal effects are not known, emerging evidence points to modifications in events that lead to chromatin assembly, DNA replication, and methylation.

CI induced by Wolbachia in Drosophila leads to delays in histones H3.3 and H4 deposition and retention of the replication factor proliferating cell nuclear antigen in the male pronucleus leading to incomplete replication of DNA during early interphase (Landmann, Orsi, Loppin, & Sullivan, 2009) . These events lead to mitotic condensation and segregation defects observed in the developing embryo, causing lethality. Notably, expression studies revealed that expression of the Hira gene is significantly reduced in Wolbachia-infected Drosophila males (wMel and wRi strains) that show strong CI compared to those that are not infected or show no CI (Zheng, Ren, Wang, & Wang, 2011) . HIRA is a chaperone of histone H3.3, which is involved in deposition of H3.3-H4 tetramers in the male pronucleus and therefore proper assembly of chromatin (Loppin et al., 2005) . Similar to CI embryos, mating of male flies with mutations in Hira with uninfected female flies led to significantly lower hatch rate (Zheng et al., 2011) . The results clearly demonstrated the correlation of CI with reduced Hira expression levels.

In the leafhopper, Zyginidia pullula, Wolbachia-induced feminization of genetic males was shown to correlate with genomic imprints that had the same pattern as females (Negri et al., 2009) . This effect was shown to be density dependent, with the female genomic imprint and female phenotypes (e.g., having ovaries) in the feminized males correlating with higher Wolbachia densities (Negri et al., 2009) . The genomic imprints were determined by methylation-sensitive random amplification of polymorphic DNA polymerase chain reaction suggesting Wolbachia infection in males leads to alterations in DNA methylation that affect genes involved in sex differentiation and development. In another example, Wolbachia density was shown to affect sex ratio in Drosophila innubila by inducing male killing (Dyer, Minhas, & Jaenike, 2005) . Bacterial density was found to be an epigenetic and heritable trait, whereby at higher Wolbachia densities females had a more female-biased offspring sex ratio. It was proposed that Wolbachia might interfere with steroid hormone signaling, which is implicated in interactions with nuclear receptor coregulators as key modulators in DNA methylation and chromatin remodeling (Negri, 2012) . However, this hypothesis needs to be experimentally explored. Wolbachia-induced feminization has also been reported in butterflies (Narita, Kageyama, Nomura, & Fukatsu, 2007) and isopods (Cordaux, Michel-Salzat, Frelon-Raimond, Rigaud, & Bouchon, 2004) .

In addition to the above report in the leafhopper on differential genome methylation induced by Wolbachia associated with feminization, a recent study demonstrated that Wolbachia affects the pattern of cysteine DNA methylation of infected Aedes aegypti mosquitoes (Ye et al., 2013) . This could potentially be responsible for differential expression of a large number of host genes in Wolbachia-infected A. aegypti (Rancès, Ye, Woolfit, McGraw, & O'Neill, 2012) and other species (Kambris et al., 2010; Kremer et al., 2012) . Similar to Drosophila, there is only one DNA methyltransferase (Dnmt2) gene in the A. aegypti's genome. Both Drosophila and A. aegypti lack Dnmt1 and Dnmt3 responsible for maintenance of methylation and de novo methylation ( Marhold et al., 2004) . Overall, Wolbachia (strain wMelPop) infection in A. aegypti mosquitoes was associated with hypomethylation/demethylation of genomic DNA, both in promoters and within genes, affecting 699 genes, such as those involved in apoptosis, defense response, phagocytosis, circadian rhythms, life span, and locomotion behavior (Marhold et al., 2004; Rancès et al., 2012; Ye et al., 2013) . However, despite this significant demethylation, in comparison to noninfected A. aegypti, 63 additional genes were methylated in wMelPop-infected mosquitoes corresponding mainly to the gene ontology (GO) membranes and calcium ion transmembrane transport functional annotations (e.g., odorant receptor genes, ion transporter genes involved in locomotion and regulation of apoptosis). However, expression of a selected number of the methylated genes did not seem to significantly differ between infected and noninfected mosquitoes (Ye et al., 2013) . It remains to be established whether these changes in the methylation pattern in Wolbachiainfected mosquitoes, which are more toward GO term membranes, are specific and targeted to facilitate colonization of the host and optimize utilization of host resources by affecting genes involved in transport and communication through membranes. Relevant to this observation, it was recently shown that an A. aegypti miRNA, aae-miR-2940, which is upregulated in wMelPopinfected mosquitoes, negatively regulates the transcript levels of the Dnmt2 gene (AaDnmt2) in the mosquito (Zhang, Hussain, O'Neill, & Asgari, 2013) , which may contribute to hypomethylation of genomic DNA observed in wMelPop-infected mosquitoes (Ye et al., 2013 ) (see Section 6).

In addition to reproductive manipulations, the wMelPop strain causes life shortening in their hosts providing a means to utilize them for control of vector-borne diseases considering that most pathogens require an extrinsic incubation period to be transmissible (Cook, McMeniman, & O'Neill, 2008) (Figure 10 .1). Furthermore, this strain induces increased locomotor activity and metabolism in infected A. aegypti mosquitoes (Evans et al., 2009) , which affect female probing and blood feeding behavior when they age since they fail to complete the process of blood feeding efficiently (Moreira, Saig, et al., 2009) . It remains to be established whether alterations in methylation caused by Wolbachia infection could account for the effects but a number of genes that were found to be differentially methylated show relevance (e.g., odorant receptor genes, ion transports involved in muscle movements and life span) (Ye et al., 2013) .

An emergent new avenue in the control of vector-borne diseases was the discovery that Wolbachia protects host insects from infection by inhibiting replication of RNA, but not DNA, viruses in Drosophila (Hedges, Brownlie, O'Neill, & Johnson, 2008; Teixeira, Ferreira, & Ashburner, 2008) . This led to the transinfection of mosquitoes with particular Wolbachia strains that suppress virus infection. Mosquitoes infected with these Wolbachia strains show limited replication of arboviruses such as dengue, yellow fever and chikungunya viruses and are also refractory to other vector-borne pathogens such as filarial nematodes and the malaria parasite, Plasmodium (Bian et al., 2013; Blagrove, Arias-Goeta, Di Genua, Failloux, & Sinkins, 2013; Hughes, Koga, Xue, Fukatsu, & Rasgon, 2011; Kambris, Cook, Phuc, & Sinkins, 2009; Moreira, Iturbe-Ormaetxe, et al., 2009) . The exact molecular mechanism(s) underlying the inhibitory effect of Wolbachia on replication of several pathogens in the hosts is not clearly understood. Research indicates that this might be due to a combination of factors that may work synergistically, such as competition for resources (Caragata et al., 2013) , immune induction (Pan et al., 2012) , and possibly alteration in methylation (Zhang et al., 2013) . Overexpression of the AaDnmt2 gene in mosquito cells without Wolbachia showed increased replication of the dengue virus in the cells (Zhang et al., 2013) . Given that Wolbachia infection, via induction of the miRNA aae-miR-2940, negatively regulates AaDnmt2, dengue virus replication could be reduced as a consequence. However, the mechanism by which AeDnmt2 facilitates dengue virus replication is not known and requires further investigation.

body_text.text: In a parasitoid wasp Asobara tabida, which parasitizes the larvae of Drosophila, Wolbachia has become a primary symbiont and an epigenetic source Figure 10 .1 Wolbachia's impacts on the host. Wolbachia is mostly known for reproductive manipulations of the host including cytoplasmic incompatibility, feminization, and male killing. A number of Wolbachia strains have been transinfected into mosquito vectors of arboviruses, nematodes, and Plasmodium. In addition to reproductive effects, the introduced endosymbionts have been shown to reduce longevity, alter bloodfeeding behavior and most importantly inhibit replication of a number of vector-borne pathogens. These effects are seemingly due to epigenetic effects imposed by the endosymbiont on the host leading to alterations in the host transcriptome, which may regulate a range of phenotypic effects exerted by the carrying insects. (See the color plate.) of developmental signals since its presence is essential for successful completion of oogenesis (Dedeine, Boulétreau, & Vavre, 2005) . In female wasps without Wolbachia, oocytes undergo apoptosis leading to the lack of production of viable eggs. Transcriptomic studies revealed differential expression of genes from various biological processes such as development, apoptosis, and immunity that may play a role in the maintenance of Wolbachia within the host (Kremer et al., 2012) . It would be of great interest to explore the molecular mechanisms underlying the manipulation of gene expression by Wolbachia in a system that represents an obligatory interaction.

The tsetse fly, Glossina spp., is a vector of the sleeping sickness disease caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. The fly harbors three symbionts, Wigglesworthia glossinida, Sodalis glossinidius, and Wo. pipientis (Balmand, Lohs, Aksoy, & Heddi, 2013) . They are all vertically transmitted to the next generation, either through milk glands (Wi. glossinida and S. glossinidius) or egg cytoplasm (Wolbachia). Among the three, Wi. glossinida, an obligate intracellular mutualist, is essential for the fly's nutrition, fertility, and maturation of its immune system (Nogge, 1981; Weiss, Wang, & Aksoy, 2011) . Wigglesworthia are found within bacteriocyte cells housed in the bacteriome organ in the fly's anterior midgut (Balmand et al., 2013; Cheng & Aksoy, 1999) providing essential vitamins for the fly as vertebrate blood is low in vitamins (Nogge, 1981) . This ancient association is believed to have contributed to the reduced genome size of the bacterium shedding off unnecessary genes due to its obligate association with its host (Wernegreen, 2002) . Similar patterns of genome reductions have also been observed in bacterial genomes inhabiting insect gut environments, such as Buchnera in aphids and Ishikawaella capsulate in stinkbug Megacopta punctatissima (Nikoh, Hosokawa, Oshima, Hattori, & Fukatsu, 2011) . Research has also indicated extensive reductions and conversions to pseudogenes in the S. glossinidius genome, as a result of coevolution of the bacterium with tsetse flies (Toh et al., 2006) . However, under host-level selection, the endosymbionts retain essential genes that are required for maintenance of their symbiotic interaction (Wernegreen, 2002) . For example, Wigglesworthia retains genes involved in the synthesis of vitamin B and cofactors (Aksoy & Rio, 2006) .

A unique feature of Wigglesworthia-tsetse fly association is tight regulation of gene expression in the endosymbiont associated with different tissues and developmental stages of the host (Nogge, 1981) . The fly also transmits peptidoglycan recognition protein (PGRP-LB) through its milk to the developing progeny, which seems to protect Wigglesworthia against the host immune system (Wang & Aksoy, 2012) . Reductions in the protein lead to reduced population of the endosymbiont due to production of antimicrobial peptides, such as attacin, which destroy Wigglesworthia. The resulting flies have reduced fecundity and are hyperimmune. The induction of PGRP-LB expression by Wigglesworthia is a transgenerational effect suggesting an epigenetic effect of the endosymbiont on the host flies, although the molecular mechanism underlying the control of expression is yet to be determined.

A variety of commensal bacteria inhabit the intestinal tract of vertebrates in millions and contribute to the general well-being of their hosts by modulating their physiology and maintenance of the intestinal homeostasis (Nagy-Szakal & Kellermayer, 2011). These microbiota are largely influenced by diet since evidence suggests that people in different geographical regions have different profiles of microbiome (Muegge et al., 2011) . Tight regulation of immune functions and inflammation are essential for the maintenance of the symbiosis, which may otherwise lead to gastrointestinal disorders such as autoimmune and inflammatory bowel disease (Mazmanian, Liu, Tzianabos, & Kasper, 2005; Tlaskalová-Hogenová et al., 2011) and asthma (Azad & Kozyrskyj, 2012) . For example, in humans, Toll-like receptors (TLRs) as part of the nuclear factor kappa B immune pathway are expressed at low levels to avoid overstimulation of inflammation (Rakoff-Nahoum, Paglino, Eslami-Varzaneh, Edberg, & Medzhitov, 2004) . Overexpression of TLRs has been shown to lead to inflammatory bowel disease due to increased responses to commensal bacteria (Abreu et al., 2003) . Interestingly, downregulation of the lipopolysaccharide-sensing receptor TLR4 in intestinal epithelial cells, which provides a barrier between the intestinal lumen and internal organs, and consequently their reduced sensitivity has been shown to be due to DNA methylation and histone deacetylation induced by commensal bacteria (Takahashi, Sugi, Hosono, & Kaminogawa, 2009; Takahashi et al., 2011) . This leads to inhibition of excessive inflammation and tolerance of a large number of commensal bacteria in the intestinal lumen. How the commensal bacteria contribute to DNA methylation is an interesting question that deserves investigation. It was speculated that the symbionts might alter expression or modification of factors that recruit DNA methyltransferases to specific sequences on the genes involved in modulation of immune responses (Takahashi et al., 2011) .

There are lines of evidence pointing to the involvement of the gut symbionts metabolic end products in the epigenetic effects. For example, folate derivatives produced by microbiota act as cofactors in one-carbon (C1) transfer reactions utilized in the synthesis of a variety of essential compounds that contribute to DNA methylation (reviewed in Nagy-Szakal & Kellermayer, 2011) . In addition, short-chain fatty acids are presumably involved in epigenetic regulation of inflammatory responses mediated by free fatty acid receptors (FFARs) (Pegorier, Le May, & Girard, 2004) . In a recent study, it was shown that the composition of the gut microbiota differs in obese and type 2 diabetic individuals with the diversity of the microbiota being significantly lower in these two groups of patients compared to normal-weight individuals. This coincided with significantly lower methylation of CpGs in the promoter region of the FFAR3 gene in the obese and type 2 diabetic individuals (Remely et al., in press ). The investigators suggested that interventions based on diet that could alter the composition of microbiota could be considered as an option for managing the metabolic syndromes. Similarly, the association of epigenetics with microbiota-host interactions could be explored in a number of other disorders, including brain and behavior disorders (Stilling, Dinan, & Cryan, 2014) and cancer (Serban, in press; Yang, Owen, Lightfoot, Kladde, & Mohamadzadeh, 2013) , which involve imbalances in the gut microbiota.

The effect of gut microbiota in the development of the immune system and its association with the perinatal programming of asthma has also been documented (Azad & Kozyrskyj, 2012) . Accordingly, delayed colonization or altered profile of the microbiota may facilitate development of chronic allergies in infants. This has led to proposed treatments with probiotic bacteria that restore gut hemostasis to minimize risks of stress-related allergies. The exact mechanism(s) by which probiotic bacteria mediate their effects in prevention of allergy or intestinal diseases is yet to be understood, but circumstantial evidence suggest their capacity in modifying the epigenetics of the host by altering the host DNA methylation or inhibiting histone deacetylase, which represses transcription by tightening the chromatin structure (Licciardi, Wong, Tang, & Karagiannis, 2010) . These epigenetic effects might play important roles in regulating transcription of key genes involved in the modulation of host immunity.

miRNAs are small noncoding RNAs of ∼22 nucleotides, which have been recognized as key regulators of gene expression both at transcriptional and posttranscriptional levels adding to the complexity of gene regulation. Involvement of miRNAs in almost all cellular pathways affecting a variety of biological functions has been documented, including development, digestion, immunity, cancer, host-pathogen interactions, and symbiosis. With the development of new molecular and bioinformatics tools used for small RNA research, our knowledge of miRNA biogenesis and function has been rapidly expanding, with over 24,000 miRNAs already identified and deposited in the miRBase (www.mirbase.org), the main repository for miRNAs (Kozomara & Griffiths-Jones, 2011) .
body_text.section: MicroRNAs AS EPIGENETIC REGULATORS OF SYMBIOTIC ASSOCIATIONS

body_text.text: Mature miRNAs exert their function by binding to their target transcripts in association with the RNA-induced silencing complex, which leads to repression of translation, degradation of mRNA (Ameres & Zamore, 2013; Bartel, 2009) , and sometimes an increase in the target transcript levels by inducing transcription or increasing the stability of mRNA (Vasudevan, 2012) . While in plants complete complementarity of the miRNA and target sequences is essential, in animals mismatches are normal. In addition to interacting with mRNAs, miRNAs may also regulate gene expression by interacting with the promoter regions of various genes, facilitating their methylation and consequently gene silencing (Kim, Saetrom, Snøve, & Rossi, 2008) .
body_text.section: MicroRNAs AS EPIGENETIC REGULATORS OF SYMBIOTIC ASSOCIATIONS

body_text.text: As mentioned in Section 6, gut microbiota play important roles in the maturation of gut immune responses and maintenance of immune homeostasis in animals. This involves tight regulation of genes that are involved in recognition and immune responses. Emerging evidence suggests that miRNAs are implicated in immune modulation in intestinal cells (reviewed in Staedel & Darfeuille, 2013) . For example, mouse miR-10a was shown to be negatively regulated through TLR-TLR ligand interaction by commensal bacteria in mucosal dendritic cells (Xue et al., 2011) . The targets of this miRNA were determined to be interleukin (IL)-12 and IL-23 proteins, which share a p40 subunit. By downregulating miR-10a, expression of the target genes is stimulated, leading to the establishment of a low inflammatory response in the intestine that contributes to the progression of intestinal inflammation and maintenance of host immune homeostasis. In another study, it was demonstrated that miR-146a is induced in the mouse gut following exposure to gut microbiota, which mediates translational repression and proteolytic degradation of interleukin 1 receptor-associated kinase 1 that is an essential TLR signaling molecule (Chassin et al., 2010) . This leads to induction of intestinal epithelial innate immune tolerance and therefore contributes toward intestinal homeostasis. Furthermore, Singh et al. revealed that the murine cecal miRNA signature is altered by endogenous microbiota, which affects the regulation of the barrier function and intestinal homeostasis by modulating genes involved in these processes (Singh et al., 2012) .
body_text.section: MicroRNAs AS EPIGENETIC REGULATORS OF SYMBIOTIC ASSOCIATIONS

body_text.text: Microarray analysis of A. aegypti mosquito miRNAs revealed that several miRNAs were significantly differentially expressed in mosquitoes infected with the wMelPop strain of Wolbachia (Hussain, Frentiu, Moreira, O'Neill, & Asgari, 2011) . One of these miRNAs, aae-miR-2940, was highly upregulated in Wolbachia-infected mosquitoes. Two targets of this miRNA were determined to be the host's metalloprotease m41 ftsh (Hussain et al., 2011) and DNA methyltransferase AaDnmt2 (Zhang et al., 2013) transcripts. Interestingly, the miRNA positively and negatively regulates the metalloprotease and AaDnmt2 transcript levels, respectively. Experiments revealed that silencing of the metalloprotease gene (induced by Wolbachia) by injection of dsRNA or inhibition of aae-miR-2940 by injection of the synthetic antagomir led to reduction in Wolbachia density (Hussain et al., 2011) . In regards to AaDnmt2, significant declines were found in the gene's transcript levels in Wolbachia-infected whole mosquitoes and various tissues tested (ovaries, midgut, muscles, and salivary glands). Consistently, it was found that in Wolbachia-infected A. aegypti mosquitoes there is a significant difference in DNA methylation as compared to noninfected mosquitoes showing an overall substantial demethylation/hypomethylation in mosquitoes harboring Wolbachia (Ye et al., 2013) . As a consequence, differential expression of a large number of genes in Wolbachia-infected mosquitoes (Rancès et al., 2012) could be due to their differential DNA methylation, which affects their expression. This suggests that Wolbachia manipulates the host's transcriptome by modifying DNA methylation via regulation of host miRNAs. Notably, induction of aae-miR-2940 and subsequent suppression of AaDnmt2 was found to be essential for Wolbachia maintenance, since overexpression of the protein in Wolbachia-infected cells led to significant reductions in the symbiont's density in a concentration-dependent manner (Zhang et al., 2013) . Interestingly, suppression of AaDnmt2 by Wolbachia via induction of aae-miR-2940 was shown to contribute to inhibition of dengue virus replication in a cell line model, suggesting it protects mosquitoes against viral infection. Although the mechanism underlying virus inhibition is not fully understood, it appears that AaDnmt2 facilitates dengue virus replication (Zhang et al., 2013) , and suppression of the protein may contribute to its inefficient replication.
body_text.section: MicroRNAs AS EPIGENETIC REGULATORS OF SYMBIOTIC ASSOCIATIONS

body_text.text: Wolbachia is also symbiotically associated with filarial nematodes that cause diseases such as onchocerciasis (river blindness) and elephantiasis (blockage of lymphatics), and those are transmitted by insect vectors. This association is mutualistic-obligatory in which Wolbachia controls the nematode's development and fecundity and the nematode's survival depends on the endosymbiont (Taylor, Bandi, & Hoerauf, 2005) . This has provided a novel approach to treat the diseases using antibiotics to clear Wolbachia, which eventuate to the demise of the nematodes (Slatko, Taylor, & Foster, 2010) . Two developmental pauses in the nematode's life cycle are important for successful transmission of the nematode: first instar (microfilaria) for being taken up from the vertebrate host through blood feeding, and the third instar, which is the infectious stage for transmission from the vector to the vertebrate host. Recent analysis of miRNAs from the human filarial parasite Brugia malayi revealed stage-specific regulation of miRNA abundance in the nematodes, which may regulate expression of genes crucial in development (Scott et al., 2012) . For example, miR-71 and miR-34 are abundantly expressed in microfilariae. Although their direct role in establishment of symbiosis and regulation of development is yet to be established, the preliminary results point to epigenetic control of the filarial genomes by miRNAs (probably by both Wolbachia and insect vectors).
body_text.section: MicroRNAs AS EPIGENETIC REGULATORS OF SYMBIOTIC ASSOCIATIONS

body_text.text: In plants, during the process of establishment of rhizobia-legume symbiosis, which is initiated upon nitrogen stress of the host plant, dynamic alterations in a number of bacterial and plant genes are required to facilitate the events involved. These include initiation of the molecular dialogue between the two organisms, microbial infection, and formation of root nodules where bacterial nitrogen fixation occurs. Experimental evidence implicates involvement of miRNAs in these processes. For example, upon nitrogen deficiency in Arabidopsis, the primary miRNAs (pri-miRNA) for miR-169h-n and miR-398a were downregulated, while those of miR-156e, miR-156g, and miR-157d were upregulated (Pant et al., 2009) . Likewise, during the early stages of nodule development, a number of miR-NAs were identified that were differentially regulated in soybean roots in response to rhizobium, Bradyrhizobium japonicum (Subramanian et al., 2008) . For instance, miR-168, miR-172, miR-159, and miR-393 were upregulated and miR-160 and miR-169 were downregulated within the first 3 h following inoculation. In other studies, it was demonstrated that overexpression of miR-160 (Turner et al., 2013) and miR-169 (Combier et al., 2006) led to reduced/delayed nodule formation suggesting the miRNAs have important roles in rhizobia-host plant interaction. Of note, miR-393 that is upregulated as part of plant defense responses to plant pathogens (Navarro et al., 2006 ) was found to be induced following inoculation of the symbiotic rhizobium, implying overlap of miRNAs involved in plant defense and early stages of rhizobia infection. In Lotus japonicus, a noncanonical isoform of miR-171 was found induced during the rhizobial symbiont M. loti infection in nodules, and targeting the nodulation transcription factor nodulation signaling pathway 2 (NSP2) (De Luis et al., 2012) . Similarly, the role of miR-171h was implicated in arbuscular mycorrhizal colonization of Medicago truncatula by targeting NSP2 (Lauressergues et al., 2012) , which suggests that conserved miRNAs could be involved in various types of plant root symbiosis. Alternatively, this miRNA could be part of the host plant immune response to infection, which is also triggered during colonization of roots by microbiota. Inhibition of NSP2 by miR-171, which suppresses overcolonization of host plant roots by the symbiotic fungus Rhizophagus irregularis, certainly supports this hypothesis.
body_text.section: MicroRNAs AS EPIGENETIC REGULATORS OF SYMBIOTIC ASSOCIATIONS

body_text.text: Differential expression of miRNAs in established root nodules as compared to root parts without nodules has also been shown. For example, in M. truncatula, miR-2586 and miR-107 are abundantly found in the nodule meristem, while miR-396 is more abundant in the root tips (Lelandais-Brière et al., 2009) . Further, in a later stage of nodulation in L. japonicus, miR-397 was found induced in mature nitrogen-fixing nodules, while absent from noninfected roots or inactive nodules (De Luis et al., 2012) . miR-397 apparently contributes to nitrogen fixation-related copper homeostasis by targeting a member of the laccase copper protein family. The investigators suggested the possibility of utilizing miRNAs as markers to assess efficiency of symbiotic interactions given that inefficient associations may cause significant yield losses. While there are a number of reports on the role of plant host miRNAs in symbiosis, there is no information in regards to potential small noncoding RNAs in modulating genes from plant symbiotic microorganisms that might be important for the establishment of symbiosis.
body_text.section: MicroRNAs AS EPIGENETIC REGULATORS OF SYMBIOTIC ASSOCIATIONS

body_text.text: In a holobiont, comprising the host and all its symbiont population, success of the holobiont depends on the success of parties involved in the interactions. A general phenomenon observed from examining various host-symbiont interactions is that the host's and/or the symbiont's gene expression patterns are reciprocally modulated by its partner. A unifying theme is the contribution of microbiota in the development and regulation of the host immune system to minimize the risk of elimination and hyperimmune responses, which assists the establishment of mutualistic/ commensalistic microorganisms. This, in many instances, may lead to better protection of the host against pathogenic microorganisms. On the other hand, some of the effectors or regulators that are associated with pathogenicity are typically removed or epigenetically controlled during the process of symbiogenesis. Indeed, epigenetic plasticity (nonheritable and unstable changes) and/or epigenetic inheritance have been implicated in these processes.

Despite a large amount of interest in symbiotic interactions, relatively little is known about the epigenetic effects underlying host-symbiont interactions, which ironically appear to play significant roles in the associations. Exposure of endosymbionts to environmental stress may impose constraints on the host's functional plasticity and hence affect their adaptation to new environmental conditions, e.g., heat stress and global warming (Wernegreen, 2012) , as shown in insects (Fan & Wernegreen, 2013) and corals (Fitt, Brown, Warner, & Dunne, 2001) . With a better understanding of the interactions at the molecular level, including epigenetic effects, the detrimental environmental effects on mutualistic microorganisms on which survival and wellbeing of the host depends could possibly be averted. In addition, imbalances in gut microbiota have been associated with epigenetic changes leading to disorders in humans. Although less, recent research is providing great promises for better management of these disorders by increasing our awareness of the epigenetic effects underlying microbiota-human/animal interactions that can be influenced by manipulation of microbial populations or dietary supplements. This emphasizes the need for more intensive research in this poorly investigated area.

An interesting avenue of research is to investigate cross-kingdom communications between host and endosymbiont via small noncoding RNAs leading to plastic or heritable epigenetic effects. Although information is almost nonexistent in regard to mutualistic interactions, research from pathogenic interactions seems to suggest their involvement in the communications. A recent study demonstrated translocation of enriched miRNAs from sickle cell erythrocytes (resistant to malaria) into the malaria parasite, Plasmodium falciparum, resulting in the impairment of ribosomal loading and hence translational inhibition (LaMonte et al., 2012) . Another research revealed crosskingdom RNAi utilized by a pathogenic fungus, Botrytis cinerea, to hijack the host plant RNAi pathway by binding to Arabidopsis AGO1 and selectively silencing genes involved in host immunity (Weiberg et al., 2013) . It is highly likely that mutualistic organisms communicate with each other via small regulatory RNAs to modify gene expression patterns of the involved parties to facilitate establishment of symbiotic associations. This is a fascinating avenue of research to follow, as there is currently nothing known in this area.

Considering that genetic data do not sufficiently explain all the phenotypic manifestations in a living organism, epigenetic effects continue to explain some of these gaps. In particular, the role of symbionts and microbiota in producing variations in the host gene expression is of special interest. It is hoped that this chapter raises interest among researchers working on host-symbiont interactions to further explore the epigenetic mechanisms underlying symbiotic interactions.
